awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Models and Measurements for Website Fingerprinting
awd_abstract_narration:
Many private interactions between individuals and their friends, families, employers, and institutions are now carried out on the Internet; disclosure of the contents of these interactions or even the mere associations between these parties can expose people to real financial or physical risks. As a result, encryption and services such as virtual private networks or the Tor project that conceal the connection between a user and the websites they visit are growing in popularity.  Website fingerprinting attacks use information that is not concealed by these techniques, such as file sizes and download times, to re-identify the websites a user visits, but while these attacks work in a lab environment, it is a challenge to evaluate them in practical settings and develop effective protections against them.  This project will apply statistics and machine learning to develop new probabilistic models of the "fingerprint" of a website, metrics of the amount of information these models reveal, and privacy preserving algorithms and datasets to test these models.  The results of these models and tests will be used to assess the threat posed by website fingerprinting and inform the design of new defense mechanisms.  As a result, users will benefit from improved protection techniques, while other researchers can use the resulting models, datasets, and metrics to study the effectiveness of website fingerprinting defenses.  The work and data will also be used to support both undergraduate and graduate education through both courses and research training.

This project will seek to address three key challenges in website fingerprinting research -- privacy-preserving characterization of background traffic, maintaining fingerprint databases, and evaluation and comparison of defenses -- by developing new representations of website fingerprints that can assign a likelihood to any fingerprint being generated by a specific type of download.  Using these representations, the project will pursue four main thrusts.  First, the project will use these models to determine the extent to which website fingerprints can directly infer identifying features of a download without requiring a database of all possible web pages, moving from existing closed world approaches to website fingerprinting toward more broadly applicable open world approaches.  Second, the project will develop algorithms to train the models on live traffic while preserving the privacy of individual users using concepts from differential privacy.  Third, using the trained models, the project will provide the first assessment of attacks and defenses on realistic data, and use metrics from information theory to compare those attacks and defenses on an equal footing.  Finally, the project will use the results of these evaluations to develop new defensive techniques that can be applied directly to the content of privacy-sensitive sites and to systems designed to protect users' downloads such as the Tor network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Many private interactions between individuals and their friends, families, employers, and institutions are now carried out on the Internet; disclosure of the contents of these interactions or even the mere associations between these parties can expose people to real financial or physical risks. As a result many web sites support encryption and services ? such as virtual private networks, iCloud private relay, or the Tor project ? that conceal the connection between a user and the website they visit are growing in popularity.  These tools encrypt the contents of communications, and conceal the senders and recipients by passing these encrypted contents through one or more relay hosts that are not the actual recipient or sender of the messages.
Website Fingerprinting attacks use information that is not concealed by these techniques, such as file sizes and download times, to re-identify the websites a user visits, but while these attacks work in a lab environment, it is a challenge to evaluate them in practical settings and develop effective protections against them.   This project applied statistics and machine learning to develop new probabilistic models of the fingerprint of a website, new methods to analyze the effectiveness of website fingerprinting attacks, and new methods to defend against these attacks.
The first result of the project is the WeFDE framework for modeling website fingerprints.  This framework allows estimation of the amount of information that can be extracted from a website fingerprint after a defense mechanism has been deployed.  It was used to show that several published and widely-cited defense mechanisms at the time did not reduce the information present in a website fingerprint, and has since been used by many other researchers as a key evaluation point for website fingerprinting defenses.  
The project also developed new models of website fingerprinting and traffic analysis attacks.  We used deep learning methods to automatically discover more useful features for fingerprinting websites, and were able to more accurately attribute the success of deep learning to this feature discovery rather than the more sophisticated classification abilities of deep learning models.  The project also studied the task of classifying individual pages on a website, showing that generative adversarial models could be used to help generate examples of pages that do not appear in the training set.  Additionally, the project identified new methods of conducting website "flow correlation" attacks that drastically reduce the false positive rate of these attacks, motivating further research into defending against website fingerprinting attacks.
The project also developed new methods to classify and evaluate website fingerprinting defenses.  We showed that existing evaluation methods did not accurately reflect the overhead caused by defenses that inject "padding" to change the fingerprint of a website, and also identified additional deficiencies in existing evaluations, such as the lack of adversarial re-training, the requirement of large databases of traffic information, and the lack of common adversary models.  The project developed a large dataset to allow common evaluation of defenses, and investigated a framework for expressing defenses in a common format.
Finally, the project developed new data-driven mechanisms to defend against website fingerprinting and flow correlation attacks.  These mechanisms used models of existing flows and our new evaluation frameworks to add additional padding and delays that cause many website to have similar fingerprints while keeping both the bandwidth overhead and delay overhead small.  We developed prototype implementations of these defenses and released them as open source software. 
Overall, the project produced data sets, software prototypes, and new evaluation methodologies that can be used by developers and other researchers to evaluate and deploy more efficient and private communication tools.  It resulted in changes to the Tor network's software and developer documentation, directly impacting the privacy of millions of users worldwide.  The project additionally contributed to the education of hundreds of undergraduate students through course lectures, as well as the research training of seven undergraduates and five graduate students.


Last Modified: 09/08/2023
Modified by: Nicholas J Hopper
